document.title: Elementary Science Core Curriculum Grades K-4

35ACA9463B2045BCA64157ADBC4F5691.description: Humans, as individuals or communities, change environments in ways that can be either helpful or harmful for themselves and other organisms.

8EC7A043DD6846F08B0402EA2EB9E44E.description: Over time humans have changed their environment by cultivating crops and raising animals, creating shelter, using energy, manufacturing goods, developing means of transportation, changing populations, and carrying out other activities.

FD5388EC788040C48DDD9FAECE9C6394.description: Humans depend on their natural and constructed environments.

BE0C80BA2E9E47D48BBEC7F8B56FB5E2.description: Identify ways in which humans have changed their environment and the effects of those changes.

4C8210C00C0246D78954AB9FFEA81966.description: Human decisions and activities have had a profound impact on the physical and living environments.

7266C6E4A7E54EB987456904C26ECA25.description: Heat energy from the Sun powers the water cycle (see Physical Science Key Idea 2).

8D3E4A4F136B4731985574B59B9A9978.description: The Sun’s energy is transferred on Earth from plants to animals through the food chain.

EFD2FD0AC3814FE6B6BF145EB1C1A8E5.description: Plants manufacture food by utilizing air, water, and energy from the Sun.

B728769710D740D28047BC805A2ABCE0.description: Describe the relationship of the Sun as an energy source for living and nonliving cycles.

2CE400940311426CBD340CD721C470E8.description: Plants and animals depend on each other and their physical environment.

D4B96E664BFE499782B95DE818F65D7E.description: When the environment changes, some plants and animals survive and reproduce, and others die or move to new locations.

ED40898FDED14980A4302372FC7AFFF3.description: An organism’s pattern of behavior is related to the nature of that organism’s environment, including the kinds and numbers of other organisms present, the availability of food and other resources, and the physical characteristics of the environment.

EDECEA4222CD4791B689767313719871.description: Decomposers are living things that play a vital role in recycling nutrients.

59DE7C5E74AD4D33BE3FB9B686A226DD.description: Animals that eat plants for food may in turn become food for other animals. This sequence is called a food chain.

BFE537A959AC4C41B4F105DDD4EAC4C8.description: All animals depend on plants. Some animals (predators) eat other animals (prey).

D4932FB6E4594A0CAD72E86258618D1D.description:
Green plants are producers because they provide the basic food supply for themselves
and animals.

801DB43ECE8B46F982BB32A2ECB46038.description: Describe how plants and animals, including humans, depend upon each other and the nonliving environment.

61B610BB55BF4D8CB169F4A0394F5F7C.description: Plants and animals depend on each other and their physical environment.

E885725BA576428E89C7D665DA7F37EA.description: Good health habits include hand washing and personal cleanliness; avoiding harmful substances (including alcohol, tobacco, illicit drugs); eating a balanced diet; engaging in regular exercise.

9722D4A0774A4F188C8480F13359CA45.description:
Humans need a variety of healthy foods, exercise, and rest in order to grow and
maintain good health.

9D83AA927BD94580B8692784A719DD62.description: Describe the factors that help promote good health and growth in humans.

95530CECF5BC4B1ABA801112A6C50D6E.description: Organisms maintain a dynamic equilibrium that sustains life.

9090477CA6B0426E946EE0F7597FA85E.description: The health, growth, and development of organisms are affected by environmental conditions such as the availability of food, air, water, space, shelter, heat, and sunlight.

3D8F700AD56B4D5699BD88F6BEB70F06.description: Some animal behaviors are influenced by environmental conditions. These behaviors may include: nest building, hibernating, hunting, migrating, and communicating.

42CB6BC3C1034EEF83A2197D9BB6B099.description: Particular animal characteristics are influenced by changing environmental conditions including: fat storage in winter, coat thickness in winter, camouflage, shedding of fur.

980D5CA970064060A866B020002DEC00.description: Some animals, including humans, move from place to place to meet their needs.

A3DF09EFADAE406E9504D50A04607E2F.description: Senses can provide essential information (regarding danger, food, mates, etc.) to animals about their environment.

DBA4EBBEE8EC4037AC411E3901E5935F.description: Animals respond to change in their environment, (e.g., perspiration, heart rate, breathing rate, eye blinking, shivering, and salivating).

57458662FB194EA084E31D85F4A20525.description:
Plants respond to changes in their environment. For example, the leaves of some
green plants change position as the direction of light changes; the parts of some plants
undergo seasonal changes that enable the plant to grow; seeds germinate, and leaves
form and grow.

7D2AC9E3823B47D9818983C64A6AB4E9.description: Describe some survival behaviors of common living specimens.

2479FECC10F04DA683FC89BEAA08EF64.description: Organisms maintain a dynamic equilibrium that sustains life.

9F64431229B04869A09DD272A1F0B852.description: An organism’s external physical features can enable it to carry out life functions in its particular environment.

324E08374B884CE5954FB8F58A342EDC.description: All living things grow, take in nutrients, breathe, reproduce, and eliminate waste.

0FADBDB1CEEA4DCFB5D34F1857C67C4C.description: Describe basic life functions of common living specimens (e.g., guppies, mealworms, gerbils).

20706F68FD5B4A199685690E9E43DB4A.description: Organisms maintain a dynamic equilibrium that sustains life.

D1F521E152404BD38D03347E5DD824F9.description: Food supplies the energy and materials necessary for growth and repair

F660932E5A6842BEB46EB8CD77CF1C7F.description: Growth is the process by which plants and animals increase in size.

04DAFB733855498F81F1B5548D7CB681.description: Describe evidence of growth, repair, and maintenance, such as nails, hair, and bone, and the healing of cuts and bruises.

59A2A85C829F400EB3DE732A36E61D04.description: The continuity of life is sustained through reproduction and development.

16C1B5E69E7B4EB5ADB587E9EF46DCF1.description: The length of time from an animal’s birth to its death is called its life span. Life spans of different animals vary.

3E029A7A142A47ED8CC379F7CEC39F29.description: Each kind of animal goes through its own stages of growth and development during its life span.

CBE904412E7749D183BBCA358CE67592.description: Each generation of animals goes through changes in form from young to adult. This completed sequence of changes in form is called a life cycle. Some insects change from egg to larva to pupa to adult.

1071A250657342DAB7C1F4C9566A416A.description: Life cycles of some plants include changes from seed to mature plant.

1C9D08812E604FE0A5E597993A8EBFB0.description: The length of time from beginning of development to death of the plant is called its life span

F36FA5EF5C144637A586F0900D41213B.description: Each kind of plant goes through its own stages of growth and development that may include seed, young plant, and mature plant.

202226AB1FF24A1995EDFAAA82F5BA24.description:
Plants and animals have life cycles. These may include beginning of a life, development
into an adult, reproduction as an adult, and eventually death.

DD5BC06054EA45DFA2CD84E57BDBB6F9.description: Describe the major stages in the life cycles of selected plants and animals.

2AF9F1A9AB7941A5820430E51F4F7365.description: The continuity of life is sustained through reproduction and development.

542622B2206B498C8ED86D7AC723B87C.description: All individuals have variations, and because of these variations, individuals of a species may have an advantage in surviving and reproducing.

4E6E661088EC4D869EB933726A25445E.description:
Individuals within a species may compete with each other for food, mates, space,
water, and shelter in their environment.

82B019C2E6084006998AF86BD525A723.description: Observe that differences within a species may give individuals an advantage in surviving and reproducing.

3846159FF6F547AEB224275988DB0438.description: Individual organisms and species change over time.

66A1C503C5A04A83A9C6B12D86D79890.description:
In order to survive in their environment, plants and animals must be adapted to
that environment.

CA86EDDBF5D04089B13F482B73582B92.description:
Each plant has different structures that serve different functions in growth,
survival, and reproduction

ED210CDB267746D5BED244ECD53C7242.description:
Each animal has different structures that serve different functions in growth,
survival, and reproduction.

260BC50943DB47E08B6D750AD3F117EF.description: Describe how the structures of plants and animals complement the environment of the plant or animal.

654DB36ECDEF4792A83C583D84E505BF.description: Individual organisms and species change over time.

7DC7E20B70D247ADB9F7AD32C446A2AC.description: Plants and animals can transfer specific traits to their offspring when they reproduce.

F870594A61D04D7DA25271ACD1705494.description:
Plants and animals closely resemble their parents and other individuals in their
species.

AE5A6071E6EA407495AB993A40E0FB40.description: Recognize that for humans and other living things there is genetic continuity between generations

09461103F46445BFA6AACB2453F70AC3.description: Organisms inherit genetic information in a variety of ways that result in continuity of structure and function between parents and offspring.

202BCEB5BC864A869842B39725A54941.description: Some characteristics result from an individual’s interactions with the environment and cannot be inherited by the next generation (e.g., having scars; riding a bicycle).

B568BB58142A44EFBE8F2A6EE7C1264D.description:
Some traits of living things have been inherited (e.g., color of flowers and number
of limbs of animals).

2F6B476B5FA342CDA18478EF74AEF629.description: Recognize that traits of living things are both inherited and acquired or learned

0576231E40794A30BC61E699AD497290.description: Organisms inherit genetic information in a variety of ways that result in continuity of structure and function between parents and offspring.

B694DDFC47A140F780580BCE9B060A72.description: Living things grow, take in nutrients, breathe, reproduce, eliminate waste, and die.

E19AA527D866402591AF4CE3E678D414.description: Describe the life processes common to all living things.

76B9352C586141479A48E5101962C037.description: Living things are both similar to and different from each other and from nonliving things.

540201C291CD4E25B9F6FAFAA826E767.description: Nonliving things can be human-created or naturally occurring.

6522FE8840A94FE4BFE686A597E5A030.description: Nonliving things do not live and thrive.

C96A31B091DF434EB619ED6F193987B0.description: Plants require air, water, nutrients, and light in order to live and thrive.

28DAF82039D142F4BE2BD96D16E25E7E.description: Animals need air, water, and food in order to live and thrive.

9BE4BF04F92B4F84B18F643A33688DB6.description: Describe the characteristics of and variations between living and nonliving things.

76D5A6704B8E4160834E7C42215D4554.description: Living things are both similar to and different from each other and from nonliving things.

045FFA1C410E48E2B6506AB292D9523A.description:
Students will understand and apply scientific concepts, principles, and theories pertaining to the physical
setting and living environment and recognize the historical development of ideas in science.

EAA15B3DD3CA44AE9918EDBA132887FD.description: The force of magnetism on objects decreases as distance increases.

4282CB0B2DDB44B5AEEEA8D3BD82FCE3.description:
The forces of gravity and magnetism can affect objects through gases, liquids, and
solids.

DBEE87566BD94DA1948FF9EDEA4DC53F.description: Describe how forces can operate across distances.

81D57E00FA5444F19A45C59DBA2B3717.description: Energy and matter interact through forces that result in changes in motion.

C4F0B604953449FC976443F97C316615.description:
Mechanical energy may cause change in motion through the application of force and
through the use of simple machines such as pulleys, levers, and inclined planes.

42EB36AB6712479BAEBFAC12F21B0E41.description: Magnetism is a force that may attract or repel certain materials.

93BB3A69340244D08B6EE4B10AD3054B.description: The amount of change in the motion of an object is affected by friction.

E652FEF6CF434C669C6EDDB725A4D878.description: The force of gravity pulls objects toward the center of Earth.

A0F4F429FA974E4BAC9B4079EDD4DBBD.description:
The position or direction of motion of an object can be changed by pushing or
pulling.

0806F5547CA4491180EBAD23476370C7.description:
The position of an object can be described by locating it relative to another object
or the background (e.g., on top of, next to, over, under, etc.).

CB123FA7F6204A6381CEA054312D97F0.description: Describe the effects of common forces (pushes and pulls) of objects, such as those caused by gravity, magnetism, and mechanical forces.

AB5B1847DAEF4BD9B4CB3AB0F94FCFF9.description: Energy and matter interact through forces that result in changes in motion.

4D7C28BFD6104E79BA320502DCE0A713.description:
Humans utilize interactions between matter and energy.
• chemical to electrical, light, and heat: battery and bulb
• electrical to sound (e.g., doorbell buzzer)
• mechanical to sound (e.g., musical instruments, clapping)
• light to electrical (e.g., solar-powered calculator)

73BE3F4461C24305815AF8F006301B43.description:
Everyday events involve one form of energy being changed to another.
• animals convert food to heat and motion
• the Sun’s energy warms the air and water

AF4DF5C3CF0A46779370F2FF2EE8FC20.description: Observe the way one form of energy can be transferred into another form of energy present in common situations (e.g., mechanical to heat energy, mechanical to electrical energy, chemical to heat energy).

FDEC1D000D3E439DA86B7B9EFCEDEBBC.description: Energy exists in many forms, and when these forms change energy is conserved

13386D98D6EC4D5FBFE91F85915EBF0D.description: Interactions with forms of energy can be either helpful or harmful.

29726C21F06942558E61F12AE1B36F98.description: Heat can be released in many ways, for example, by burning, rubbing (friction), or combining one substance with another.

E25FF142FFCA426EACD483E02A746696.description: Electricity travels in a closed circuit.

22E508EA925E4138ADA52E0709F5CC45.description: Energy and matter interact: water is evaporated by the Sun’s heat; a bulb is lighted by means of electrical current; a musical instrument is played to produce sound; dark colors may absorb light, light colors may reflect light.

9431925986524AECA61D2D41BB82FA73.description: Some materials transfer energy better than others (heat and electricity).

D5588C2566DB44C0827DE683E76549BD.description: Energy can be transferred from one place to another.

62671761577E46DF8B0D212452E30841.description: Energy exists in various forms: heat, electric, sound, chemical, mechanical, light.

D5D6CB27EB084C089A239C6C5465FD08.description: Describe a variety of forms of energy (e.g., heat, chemical, light) and the changes that occur in objects when they interact with those forms of energy.

7F7841B0292D4BEF9610FC40ED9033D1.description: Energy exists in many forms, and when these forms change energy is conserved.

19757F97F63B432DB2C67FE0DFB4EB33.description: Changes in the properties or materials of objects can be observed and described.

C79E58130EC148779429DD0F8BE93C78.description: Temperature can affect the state of matter of a substance.

204ECB703A12486383E50C19A6B146BD.description:
Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, gas.
• solids have a definite shape and volume
• liquids do not have a definite shape but have a definite volume
• gases do not hold their shape or volume

891EDBA6969B4F9BA7B58B3920F435B7.description: Describe chemical and physical changes, including changes in states of matter.

DD17EBADEE6C41069598D10FF0CDACAD.description: Matter is made up of particles whose properties determine the observable characteristics of matter and its reactivity

2416D08FE2F14DEB92DAB9C4F9563C09.description: Some properties of an object are dependent on the conditions of the present surroundings in which the object exists. For example: • temperature - hot or cold • lighting - shadows, color • moisture - wet or dry

45A04A7D46524F5BB9AC4D6DF64399B9.description: Objects and/or materials can be sorted or classified according to their properties.

15824B93A6734DD7A350FA4EAAF1EFDD.description: The material(s) an object is made up of determine some specific properties of the object (sink/float, conductivity, magnetism). Properties can be observed or measured with tools such as hand lenses, metric rulers, thermometers, balances, magnets, circuit testers, and graduated cylinders.

159532892AFA488DBE36BDE076BB1B0C.description: Measurements can be made with standard metric units and nonstandard units. (Note: Exceptions to the metric system usage are found in meteorology.)

0C93F4B04CA64C3F9DF22E7F72607991.description: Objects have properties that can be observed, described, and/or measured: length, width, volume, size, shape, mass or weight, temperature, texture, flexibility, reflectiveness of light.

09BDE077C8D0411D978F7D2F583DF6C0.description: Matter has properties (color, hardness, odor, sound, taste, etc.) that can be observed through the senses.

6687BECEA67C4C228F93E984B6F6C5EB.description:
Matter takes up space and has mass. Two objects cannot occupy the same place at
the same time.

6F56A9DFD8654D1C984FA7917D188161.description: Observe and describe properties of materials, using appropriate tools.

803030FCE20942C7BD331FE95061D9A5.description: Matter is made up of particles whose properties determine the observable characteristics of matter and its reactivity

38F2F1FB97F1466287EF17C35DDC0F27.description:
Extreme natural events (floods, fires, earthquakes,volcanic eruptions, hurricanes,
tornadoes, and other severe storms) may have positive or negative impacts on living
things.

3322AB7FA2AE49CEB763A5867B2623D2.description:
Erosion and deposition result from the interaction among air, water, and land.
• interaction between air and water breaks down earth materials
• pieces of earth material may be moved by air, water, wind, and gravity
• pieces of earth material will settle or deposit on land or in the water in different
places
• soil is composed of broken-down pieces of living and nonliving earth material

134E57FB588548CEA0FF27672F19FC2C.description:
Water is recycled by natural processes on Earth.
• evaporation: changing of water (liquid) into water vapor (gas)
• condensation: changing of water vapor (gas) into water (liquid)
• precipitation: rain, sleet, snow, hail
• runoff: water flowing on Earth’s surface
• groundwater: water that moves downward into the ground

365BFBC604B24F919D835B8B320A0F0C.description:
Weather can be described and measured by:
• temperature
• wind speed and direction
• form and amount of precipitation
• general sky conditions (cloudy, sunny, partly cloudy)

9EDFA1DCAE4247B683D922E34A920841.description: Weather is the condition of the outside air at a particular moment.

B85FFA095E684E3498F0D8C42511C8E3.description: Describe the relationship among air, water, and land on Earth.

3A65F69A6443481186BDD5E83A9AC2A6.description: Many of the phenomena that we observe on Earth involve interactions among components of air, water, and land.

1301E0624A084F1AB8258B9E28400AF2.description:
The Sun and other stars appear to move in a recognizable pattern both daily and
seasonally.

ED95C10B4D9F4EE588F5989511BD4C68.description:
Humans organize time into units based on natural motions of Earth:
• second, minute, hour
• week, month

4DADCB64F27047E382C230E61B765614.description:
Natural cycles and patterns include:
• Earth spinning around once every 24 hours (rotation), resulting in day and
night
• Earth moving in a path around the Sun (revolution), resulting in one Earth year
• the length of daylight and darkness varying with the seasons
• weather changing from day to day and through the seasons
• the appearance of the Moon changing as it moves in a path around Earth to
complete a single cycle

A80CC5488D1C477DB8AACFF0C1F3BACE.description: Describe patterns of daily, monthly, and seasonal changes in their environment.

9B0FA1D18C514AEA953504579C8F9DF2.description: The Earth and celestial phenomena can be described by principles of relative motion and perspective: Describe patterns of daily, monthly, and seasonal changes in their environment.
